categories.biometrics: Personal characteristics that inform training recommendations

repetition.name: repetition
repetition.description: One complete lift and lower of an exercise. Do 10 reps means doing the movement 10 times.

set.name: set
set.description: A group of reps done without stopping. 3 sets of 10 means doing 10 reps, resting, then repeating twice more.

one-repetition-maximum.name: one repetition maximum
one-repetition-maximum.description: The heaviest weight you can lift once with good form. Used to calculate training weights (like 80% of 1RM).

intensity.name: intensity
intensity.description: How heavy or hard the exercise is. Usually measured as weight lifted or percentage of your max.

volume.name: volume
volume.description: Total work done, calculated as sets × reps × weight. More volume generally means more muscle growth.
volume.details: General guidelines per muscle group per week: Maintenance requires 3-6 sets (6-10 for adults 60+). Growth requires 10-20 sets. Limit each session to ~10-11 sets per muscle. Distribute volume across 1-2 sessions per week (2-3 for adults 60+).

frequency.name: frequency
frequency.description: How often you train. Can refer to workouts per week or how many times you hit each muscle per week.

range-of-motion.name: range of motion
range-of-motion.description: How far a joint can move. Full range of motion means going through the entire movement, like a squat all the way down and up.

tempo.name: tempo
tempo.description: The speed of each rep. A 3/0/2/1 tempo means 3 seconds down, no pause, 2 seconds up, 1 second at top.

warm-up-set.name: warm-up set
warm-up-set.description: A lighter set done before your main work to prepare muscles and joints. Usually about half the weight for 12-15 reps.

working-set.name: working set
working-set.description: A set done at your target weight - the sets that count toward your training, not warm-ups.

compound-exercise.name: compound exercise
compound-exercise.description: An exercise using multiple joints at once. Squats, deadlifts, and bench press are compound movements.

isolation-exercise.name: isolation exercise
isolation-exercise.description: An exercise using only one joint. Biceps curls, leg extensions, and lateral raises are isolation movements.

basic-exercise.name: basic exercise
basic-exercise.description: A main lift that works muscles with heavy loads. Usually compound movements like squat, bench, row, and press.

auxiliary-exercise.name: auxiliary exercise
auxiliary-exercise.description: A supporting exercise done after main lifts. Targets specific muscles the basic exercises may under-emphasize.

closed-chain-exercise.name: closed-chain exercise
closed-chain-exercise.description: An exercise where your hands or feet stay fixed. Squats, push-ups, and pull-ups are closed-chain because you push against a fixed surface.

open-chain-exercise.name: open-chain exercise
open-chain-exercise.description: An exercise where your hands or feet move freely through space. Leg extensions and biceps curls are open-chain.

concentric.name: concentric
concentric.description: The lifting phase where the muscle shortens. Curling the weight up in a biceps curl is concentric.

eccentric.name: eccentric
eccentric.description: The lowering phase where the muscle lengthens under load. Lowering the weight in a biceps curl is eccentric.

isometric.name: isometric
isometric.description: Holding a position without moving. A plank or pausing mid-rep is isometric - the muscle works but doesn't change length.

agonist.name: agonist
agonist.description: The main muscle driving a movement. During a biceps curl, the biceps is the agonist.

antagonist.name: antagonist
antagonist.description: The muscle opposite the working muscle. During a biceps curl, the triceps is the antagonist and must relax to allow the movement.

synergist.name: synergist
synergist.description: A helper muscle that assists the main muscle. During a biceps curl, the brachialis helps the biceps bend the elbow.

stabilizer.name: stabilizer
stabilizer.description: A muscle that holds a joint steady without moving. Your core stabilizes your spine during a squat.

dynamic-stabilizer.name: dynamic stabilizer
dynamic-stabilizer.description: A two-joint muscle that stays roughly the same length during movement by shortening at one joint while lengthening at another.

flexion.name: flexion
flexion.description: Bending a joint to decrease the angle. Bending your elbow or bringing your thigh toward your chest is flexion.

extension.name: extension
extension.description: Straightening a joint to increase the angle. Straightening your arm or kicking your leg back is extension.

pronation.name: pronation
pronation.description: Rotating your forearm so the palm faces down, like pouring out water.

supination.name: supination
supination.description: Rotating your forearm so the palm faces up, like holding a bowl of soup.

abduction.name: abduction
abduction.description: Moving a limb away from your body's centerline. Raising your arm to the side is shoulder abduction.

adduction.name: adduction
adduction.description: Moving a limb toward your body's centerline. Lowering your arm back to your side is shoulder adduction.

hypertrophy.name: hypertrophy
hypertrophy.description: Muscle growth from training. Your existing muscle fibers get bigger rather than multiplying.

atrophy.name: atrophy
atrophy.description: Muscle shrinkage from not using it. Happens during inactivity, injury, or aging.

doms.name: DOMS
doms.description: Muscle soreness appearing 1-2 days after a workout. Caused by tiny muscle fiber tears, especially from new exercises or heavy lowering (eccentric) work.

progressive-overload.name: progressive overload
progressive-overload.description: Gradually making workouts harder over time by adding weight, reps, or sets. The key driver of long-term progress.

beginner-exercise.name: beginner exercise
beginner-exercise.description: An easy-to-learn exercise with simple technique. Machine exercises and basic bodyweight movements are beginner-friendly.
beginner-exercise.details: Examples include push-ups, goblet squats, and machine-based exercises. These movements allow trainees to focus on developing basic motor patterns and building foundational strength without excessive injury risk.

intermediate-exercise.name: intermediate exercise
intermediate-exercise.description: An exercise requiring some practice. Free weight barbell and dumbbell exercises need more skill than machines.
intermediate-exercise.details: Examples include barbell squats, dumbbell rows, and lunges. These movements build on foundational patterns and introduce greater stability challenges and loading potential.

advanced-exercise.name: advanced exercise
advanced-exercise.description: A challenging exercise requiring significant strength or skill. Pistol squats and Olympic lifts take years to master.
advanced-exercise.details: Examples include pistol squats, handstand push-ups, and Olympic lifts. These movements require substantial training experience and should only be attempted after mastering foundational and intermediate progressions.

failure.name: failure
failure.description: When you can't complete another rep with good form. Training to failure means pushing until this point.

superset.name: superset
superset.description: Two exercises done back-to-back with no rest between them. Often pairs opposite muscles like chest and back.

drop-set.name: drop set
drop-set.description: Reducing the weight after hitting failure and immediately continuing for more reps. Extends the set beyond normal failure.

forced-repetitions.name: forced repetitions
forced-repetitions.description: Extra reps done with help from a spotter after you can't complete any more on your own.

pre-exhaustion.name: pre-exhaustion
pre-exhaustion.description: Doing an isolation exercise before a compound movement for the same muscle. Like chest flies before bench press.

time-under-tension.name: time under tension
time-under-tension.description: How long your muscle works during a set. Slower reps or more reps increase time under tension.

rate-of-perceived-exertion.name: rate of perceived exertion
rate-of-perceived-exertion.description: A 1-10 scale for how hard a set feels. RPE 7 means you could do 3 more reps; RPE 10 means you had nothing left.

push.name: push
push.description: Pushing weight away from you. Bench press, overhead press, and push-ups are push exercises.

pull.name: pull
pull.description: Pulling weight toward you. Rows, pull-ups, and curls are pull exercises.

hinge.name: hinge
hinge.description: Bending forward at the hips while keeping your back flat. Deadlifts, Romanian deadlifts, and good mornings use this pattern.

squat-pattern.name: squat pattern
squat-pattern.description: Sitting down and standing up - bending at the hips, knees, and ankles together while keeping your torso upright.

resistance-curve.name: resistance curve
resistance-curve.description: How the difficulty changes through a lift's range of motion. Some exercises get harder at the top, bottom, or middle.

leg-drive.name: leg drive
leg-drive.description: Pushing your feet into the floor during bench press to create full-body tension and stability.

lockout.name: lockout
lockout.description: The end position where joints are fully straightened. The top of a squat or bench press.

sticking-point.name: sticking point
sticking-point.description: The hardest part of a lift where most people fail. On bench press, it's usually a few inches off the chest.

spotter.name: spotter
spotter.description: Someone who watches your lift and helps if you get stuck. Essential for heavy bench press and squats.

form.name: form
form.description: How you position and move your body during an exercise. Good form maximizes results and prevents injury.

target.name: target
target.description: The main muscle an exercise works. Bench press targets the chest.

origin.name: origin
origin.description: Where a muscle attaches closer to your torso. This end stays relatively still during movement.

insertion.name: insertion
insertion.description: Where a muscle attaches farther from your torso. This end moves toward the origin when the muscle contracts.

biarticulate.name: biarticulate
biarticulate.description: A muscle crossing two joints. Hamstrings cross the hip and knee, so leg position affects how much they stretch.

active-insufficiency.name: active insufficiency
active-insufficiency.description: When a two-joint muscle can't shorten enough to fully move both joints at once. Example: hamstrings can't fully extend the hip and flex the knee simultaneously.

passive-insufficiency.name: passive insufficiency
passive-insufficiency.description: When a two-joint muscle can't stretch enough to allow full movement at both joints at once. Example: tight hamstrings limit hip flexion when the knee is straight.

isotonic.name: isotonic
isotonic.description: Normal weight training where you move through a range of motion. Includes both lifting and lowering phases.

isokinetic.name: isokinetic
isokinetic.description: Movement at constant speed using specialized machines. The machine adjusts resistance to match your force throughout the rep.

sagittal-plane.name: sagittal plane
sagittal-plane.description: Imaginary vertical slice dividing the body into left and right halves. Forward/backward movements like squats happen in this plane.

frontal-plane.name: frontal plane
frontal-plane.description: Imaginary vertical slice dividing the body into front and back halves. Side-to-side movements like lateral raises happen in this plane.

transverse-plane.name: transverse plane
transverse-plane.description: Imaginary horizontal slice dividing the body into upper and lower halves. Rotational movements like twisting happen in this plane.

anterior.name: anterior
anterior.description: Toward the front of the body. Your chest is anterior to your spine.

posterior.name: posterior
posterior.description: Toward the back of the body. Your shoulder blades are posterior to your chest.

medial.name: medial
medial.description: Toward the center of the body. Your inner thigh is medial to your outer thigh.

lateral.name: lateral
lateral.description: Away from the center of the body. Your outer thigh is lateral to your inner thigh.

proximal.name: proximal
proximal.description: Closer to the torso. Your shoulder is proximal to your elbow.

distal.name: distal
distal.description: Farther from the torso. Your hand is distal to your elbow.

superior.name: superior
superior.description: Toward the head. Your shoulders are superior to your hips.

inferior.name: inferior
inferior.description: Away from the head. Your hips are inferior to your shoulders.

internal-rotation.name: internal rotation
internal-rotation.description: Rotating a limb inward toward your body's center. Turning your arm so your thumb points toward your body.

external-rotation.name: external rotation
external-rotation.description: Rotating a limb outward away from your body's center. Turning your arm so your thumb points away from your body.

circumduction.name: circumduction
circumduction.description: Moving a limb in a circle. Your arm drawing circles in the air is circumduction.

dorsiflexion.name: dorsiflexion
dorsiflexion.description: Pulling your toes up toward your shin.

plantarflexion.name: plantarflexion
plantarflexion.description: Pointing your toes down away from your shin. The motion of going up on your tiptoes.

inversion.name: inversion
inversion.description: Tilting the sole of your foot inward so it faces the other foot.

eversion.name: eversion
eversion.description: Tilting the sole of your foot outward away from the other foot.

torque.name: torque
torque.description: Rotational force around a joint. Longer limbs create more torque, making the same weight feel heavier at certain positions.

lever.name: lever
lever.description: A bone rotating around a joint. Your body uses lever systems to multiply force or speed depending on muscle attachment points.

angle-of-pull.name: angle of pull
angle-of-pull.description: The angle at which a muscle pulls on a bone. Muscles generate the most rotational force when pulling at 90 degrees to the bone.

ascending-tension-curve.name: ascending tension curve
ascending-tension-curve.description: Exercise gets easier as you complete the rep. Squats and bench press are hardest at the bottom and easiest at lockout.

descending-tension-curve.name: descending tension curve
descending-tension-curve.description: Exercise gets harder as you complete the rep. Rows and chin-ups are easiest at the bottom and hardest at the top.

bell-shaped-tension-curve.name: bell-shaped tension curve
bell-shaped-tension-curve.description: Exercise is hardest in the middle of the rep. Biceps curls are toughest when your elbow is bent at 90 degrees.

bilateral.name: bilateral
bilateral.description: Using both sides at once. Barbell squats and bench press are bilateral - both legs or arms work together.

unilateral.name: unilateral
unilateral.description: Using one side at a time. Single-leg squats and one-arm rows are unilateral - each limb works independently.

bilateral-deficit.name: bilateral deficit
bilateral-deficit.description: You can lift more total weight doing single-leg or single-arm exercises than both limbs together. A normal neurological effect.

articulation.name: articulation
articulation.description: Where bones meet to form a joint. Different joints allow different movements - knees hinge, shoulders rotate.

law-of-inertia.name: law of inertia
law-of-inertia.description: Objects resist changes in motion. Heavier weights are harder to start moving and harder to stop once moving.

law-of-acceleration.name: law of acceleration
law-of-acceleration.description: Force equals mass times acceleration. Moving heavier weights or moving faster both require more force from your muscles.

law-of-reaction.name: law of reaction
law-of-reaction.description: Every force has an equal opposite force. Push hard into the floor during a squat and the floor pushes back, driving you up.

calories.name: calories
calories.description: Energy from food. Eating enough supports muscle building and performance; eating too little hurts recovery and hormones.
calories.details: Low energy availability (LEA) occurs when caloric intake fails to meet the demands of exercise and bodily functions. Meta-analyses show LEA affects 45% of athletes and is linked to decreased endurance, coordination, and increased injury risk.

protein.name: protein
protein.description: The building block for muscle. Aim for 1.6-2.2 grams per kilogram of body weight daily when training.
protein.details: Meta-analyses of 49 studies show protein supplementation augments resistance training gains in muscle mass and strength. Benefits plateau at ~1.6 g/kg/day total intake, with older adults potentially benefiting from 1.2-1.6 g/kg/day.

fibre.name: fibre
fibre.description: Plant material your body can't digest. Supports gut health and is linked to lower disease risk. Found in vegetables, fruits, and whole grains.
fibre.details: An umbrella review of 17 million individuals found convincing evidence linking fibre intake to reduced CVD mortality, pancreatic cancer, and diverticular disease. Benefits appear dose-dependent with no upper threshold identified.

water.name: water
water.description: Staying hydrated supports performance. Losing just 2% of body weight in sweat hurts endurance, especially in heat.
water.details: Systematic reviews show fluid intake following dehydration improves continuous exercise performance, particularly at elevated temperatures. Pre-exercise hyperhydration may help delay adverse effects of fluid loss during prolonged exercise.

steps.name: steps
steps.description: Daily walking activity. More steps generally means better health, with benefits peaking around 8,000-10,000 steps per day.
steps.details: A meta-analysis of 47,471 adults found that compared to the lowest step group (~3,500 steps/day), those averaging 10,900 steps had 40-53% lower mortality risk. Benefits plateau around 6,000-8,000 steps for adults over 60, and 8,000-10,000 for younger adults.

sleep.name: sleep
sleep.description: Rest essential for recovery and muscle growth. Most people need 7-9 hours; getting more can improve athletic performance.
sleep.details: Systematic reviews show sleep extension improves reaction time, sprint performance, and shooting accuracy in athletes. Collegiate basketball players extending sleep to 10 hours showed 9% improved free-throw accuracy and faster sprint times.

recovery.name: recovery
recovery.description: A 1-10 self-rating of how ready you feel to train. Low scores suggest you need more rest before your next hard workout.
recovery.details: The Perceived Recovery Status (PRS) scale correlates with markers of muscle damage and performance decrements. Research shows it can effectively assess daily recovery following resistance exercise, though the relationship is individualized.

reps-in-reserve.name: reps in reserve
reps-in-reserve.description: How many more reps you could have done. RIR 2 means you stopped with 2 reps left in the tank.
reps-in-reserve.details: RIR provides a practical way to auto-regulate training intensity. Research suggests training within 0-3 RIR optimizes hypertrophy while managing fatigue. Higher RIR (4+) may be appropriate for technique practice or deload periods.

maintenance-volume.name: maintenance volume
maintenance-volume.description: The minimum sets per muscle per week to keep what you have. About 6 sets per muscle maintains size during busy periods.
maintenance-volume.details: Research shows young adults can maintain muscle with as few as 3 sets per muscle per week if intensity is preserved. Adults over 60 typically require 6-10 sets per week. Maintaining load (intensity) is more critical than maintaining volume.

minimum-effective-volume.name: minimum effective volume
minimum-effective-volume.description: The minimum sets per muscle per week to grow. Around 8-10 sets per muscle is where growth begins for most people.
minimum-effective-volume.details: MEV varies by training status and muscle group. Beginners may see growth with fewer sets, while advanced trainees require more. Starting a training block at MEV allows room to progressively increase volume.

maximum-adaptive-volume.name: maximum adaptive volume
maximum-adaptive-volume.description: The sweet spot for muscle growth. Around 12-18 sets per muscle per week provides the best returns for most people.
maximum-adaptive-volume.details: MAV represents the progression zone between MEV and MRV. Each session increases fatigue, requiring progressive volume increases to maintain optimal stimulus. The ideal volume varies by individual recovery capacity and training experience.

maximum-recoverable-volume.name: maximum recoverable volume
maximum-recoverable-volume.description: The most you can do and still recover. Going beyond 20-25 sets per muscle per week leads to burnout, not more growth.
maximum-recoverable-volume.details: Training at MRV is unsustainable long-term and leads to overtraining symptoms. Research suggests diminishing returns occur well before MRV, with per-session benefits plateauing around 11 sets. Distribute volume across 2-3 sessions for better results.

references.author: Remmert et al.
references.title: Is there too much of a good thing? Meta-regressions of the effect of per-session volume on hypertrophy and strength

age.name: age
age.description: Affects recovery speed and training needs. Older adults may need more frequent sessions with more recovery time between them.
age.details: Adults 60+ show better hypertrophy outcomes when training each muscle 2-3 times per week rather than once. They may need 6-10 sets per muscle weekly for maintenance (vs 3-6 for younger adults) and benefit from longer rest periods. Age-related declines in muscle protein synthesis can be offset by adequate protein intake (1.2-1.6 g/kg/day) and progressive resistance training.

sex.name: sex
sex.description: Affects strength baselines, hormones, and how body measurements relate to health. Both sexes benefit equally from resistance training.
sex.details: Males typically have higher absolute strength due to greater muscle mass and testosterone levels, but relative strength gains from training are similar between sexes. Females may recover faster between sets and sessions, potentially tolerating higher training frequencies. Sex also affects how body measurements predict health risk: males tend to accumulate visceral fat centrally while females store more subcutaneously, making waist circumference thresholds sex-specific (94 cm risk threshold for males vs 80 cm for females). Body fat percentage norms differ substantially (essential fat ~3% for males vs ~12% for females). Both sexes benefit equally from resistance training for health outcomes.

height.name: height
height.description: Affects exercise mechanics and leverage. Also used to calculate waist-to-height ratio, a useful health indicator.
height.details: For exercise: longer limbs create longer moment arms, requiring more work through the same angular range. Taller lifters often benefit from wider stances and adjusted grip widths. For health assessment: waist-to-height ratio (WHtR) is a stronger predictor of cardiometabolic risk than BMI or waist circumference alone. A WHtR below 0.5 indicates lower risk regardless of sex or ethnicity, while values above 0.6 indicate substantially elevated risk. This ratio normalizes waist measurement across different body sizes, making it more universally applicable than fixed waist thresholds.

weight.name: weight
weight.description: Your body mass in kilograms or pounds. Daily fluctuations are normal; track weekly averages for reliable trends.
weight.details: Daily weight fluctuates 1-2 kg due to hydration, food intake, and glycogen levels. Weekly averages provide more reliable trend data than single measurements. For body composition goals, the rate of weight change matters: muscle gain typically occurs at 0.25-0.5 kg/month for trained individuals, while fat loss of 0.5-1% bodyweight per week preserves muscle mass.

resting-heart-rate.name: resting heart rate
resting-heart-rate.description: Your heart rate at rest, normally 60-100 bpm. Lower is usually better. Elevated readings can signal stress or incomplete recovery.
resting-heart-rate.details: Endurance training can reduce resting heart rate by 10-20 bpm over months. Elevated resting heart rate may indicate incomplete recovery, stress, or illness. Measure first thing in the morning before rising for consistent readings. Values below 60 bpm are common in trained athletes and generally not concerning without symptoms.

evidence-level.name: Evidence level
evidence-level.description: A rating from 1 to 5 indicating how reliable a study's conclusions are. Level 1 (strongest) comes from well-designed trials; Level 5 (weakest) is expert opinion.
evidence-level.details: The Oxford Centre for Evidence-Based Medicine scale rates evidence quality: Level 1a—systematic reviews of RCTs with consistent results; Level 1b—individual RCTs with narrow confidence intervals; Level 2a—systematic reviews of cohort studies; Level 2b—individual cohort studies or low-quality RCTs; Level 3a—systematic reviews of case-control studies; Level 3b—individual case-control studies; Level 4—case series or poor-quality cohort/case-control studies; Level 5—expert opinion without critical appraisal. Higher levels provide stronger confidence in cause-and-effect relationships.

1a.name: Evidence level 1a
1a.description: Systematic review of randomized controlled trials with consistent results across studies. The strongest level of evidence.
1a.details: Level 1a represents the gold standard of evidence. These reviews pool data from multiple high-quality RCTs, providing the most reliable conclusions about cause and effect. Consistency across studies increases confidence that findings are real rather than due to chance or bias.

1b.name: Evidence level 1b
1b.description: Individual randomized controlled trial with narrow confidence intervals. Very strong evidence from a single well-designed experiment.
1b.details: Level 1b studies randomly assign participants to groups, establishing causation rather than just correlation. Narrow confidence intervals indicate precise effect estimates. These trials are the building blocks of systematic reviews and provide strong evidence when well-conducted.

2a.name: Evidence level 2a
2a.description: Systematic review of cohort studies. Moderate-strength evidence pooled from observational research.
2a.details: Level 2a synthesizes multiple cohort studies that follow participants over time. While cohorts can't prove causation like RCTs, pooling them increases statistical power and can identify consistent patterns. Useful when randomization isn't ethical or practical.

2b.name: Evidence level 2b
2b.description: Individual cohort study or low-quality RCT. Moderate evidence from following a group over time.
2b.details: Level 2b includes prospective studies tracking participants forward in time, or RCTs with methodological limitations. These identify associations and risk factors but can't definitively prove causation due to potential confounding variables.

3a.name: Evidence level 3a
3a.description: Systematic review of case-control studies. Weaker evidence pooled from studies comparing people with and without an outcome.
3a.details: Level 3a combines multiple case-control studies, which look backward from outcomes to potential causes. While pooling increases power, the retrospective design makes these prone to recall bias and confounding. Useful for rare outcomes.

3b.name: Evidence level 3b
3b.description: Individual case-control study. Compares people with an outcome to similar people without it.
3b.details: Level 3b studies identify people with a condition (cases) and match them to similar people without it (controls), then look for differences in past exposures. Efficient for rare diseases but vulnerable to selection bias and inaccurate recall.

4.name: Evidence level 4
4.description: Case series or poor-quality cohort/case-control studies. Weak evidence describing what happened to a group of patients.
4.details: Level 4 evidence describes outcomes in a series of patients without a comparison group. Can generate hypotheses and document rare phenomena, but can't establish whether observed effects are due to treatment or other factors. Often the starting point for research on new interventions.

5.name: Evidence level 5
5.description: Expert opinion without critical appraisal. The weakest evidence level, based on authority rather than research.
5.details: Level 5 represents clinical experience, physiological reasoning, or consensus without systematic research support. Valuable for areas lacking research or for practical guidance, but should be superseded by higher-level evidence when available. Includes narrative reviews and position statements.

meta-analysis.name: meta-analysis
meta-analysis.description: A study that combines data from multiple studies to find overall patterns. More reliable than single studies because it pools larger amounts of data.
meta-analysis.details: Meta-analyses statistically combine results from multiple studies, increasing sample size and statistical power. They can detect effects too small for individual studies to find. Quality depends on the included studies and methodology. Forest plots visually display individual study results and the combined effect.

systematic-review.name: systematic review
systematic-review.description: A study that finds and summarizes all research on a specific question using a rigorous, documented search method.
systematic-review.details: Systematic reviews follow predefined protocols to minimize bias. They include comprehensive literature searches, quality assessment of included studies, and transparent reporting. When combined with meta-analysis, they provide the strongest evidence. Without meta-analysis, they synthesize findings qualitatively.

umbrella-review.name: umbrella review
umbrella-review.description: A review that summarizes multiple systematic reviews on a topic. Useful for getting the big picture when many reviews exist.
umbrella-review.details: Umbrella reviews compile evidence from existing systematic reviews and meta-analyses. They're useful when a topic has been extensively studied and multiple reviews exist. They help identify consensus across reviews and highlight areas of disagreement.

randomized-controlled-trial.name: randomized controlled trial
randomized-controlled-trial.description: An experiment where participants are randomly assigned to different groups (e.g., treatment vs. control). The gold standard for testing if something actually works.
randomized-controlled-trial.details: Randomization helps ensure groups are similar at baseline, so differences in outcomes can be attributed to the intervention. Double-blinding (neither participants nor researchers know who got what) further reduces bias. RCTs establish causation, not just correlation.

intervention-study.name: intervention study
intervention-study.description: A study where researchers actively change something (like diet or exercise) and measure the effects, rather than just observing.
intervention-study.details: Intervention studies test specific changes in controlled conditions. Non-randomized intervention studies are weaker than RCTs but still provide causal evidence. Common in exercise science where blinding may be impossible (participants know if they're exercising).

cohort-study.name: cohort study
cohort-study.description: A study that follows a group of people over time to see who develops certain outcomes. Good for studying long-term effects but can't prove cause and effect.
cohort-study.details: Prospective cohorts follow participants forward in time; retrospective cohorts look back at historical data. They identify associations but can't establish causation due to confounding variables. Large cohorts like the Nurses' Health Study have provided valuable long-term health data.

cross-sectional-study.name: cross-sectional study
cross-sectional-study.description: A snapshot study that measures variables at one point in time. Quick and cheap but can't show what causes what.
cross-sectional-study.details: Cross-sectional studies capture data at a single timepoint, making them efficient but limited. They can identify correlations but not causation or temporal relationships. Useful for prevalence estimates and generating hypotheses for further research.

narrative-review.name: narrative review
narrative-review.description: An expert's summary of research on a topic. Useful for understanding a field but may be biased by the author's perspective.
narrative-review.details: Narrative reviews lack the rigorous, predefined methodology of systematic reviews. Authors may selectively cite studies supporting their views. They're valuable for introducing topics and identifying research gaps but shouldn't be the sole basis for clinical decisions.

position-statement.name: position statement
position-statement.description: Official recommendations from a professional organization based on their review of available evidence.
position-statement.details: Position statements represent expert consensus from organizations like ACSM, NSCA, or ISSN. They interpret research and provide practical recommendations. Quality varies based on the rigor of the underlying evidence review. They're updated periodically as new research emerges.

study-design.name: study design
study-design.description: The overall plan for how a study collects and analyzes data. Different designs answer different types of questions with varying levels of certainty.
study-design.details: Common study designs from strongest to weakest evidence: Systematic review with meta-analysis—pools data from multiple studies statistically; Systematic review—comprehensive summary using rigorous search methods; Umbrella review—synthesizes multiple systematic reviews; Randomized controlled trial (RCT)—randomly assigns participants to test causation; Intervention study—tests changes without randomization; Prospective cohort—follows participants forward in time; Retrospective cohort—analyzes historical data; Cross-sectional—snapshot at one timepoint; Narrative review—expert summary without systematic methods; Position statement—organization's official recommendations.

sample-size.name: sample size
sample-size.description: How many people were studied. Larger samples generally produce more reliable results and can detect smaller effects.
sample-size.details: Sample size affects statistical power—the ability to detect real effects. Small studies may miss true effects (false negatives) or find spurious ones (false positives). Meta-analyses pool samples across studies. For exercise studies, 20-30 participants per group is common; larger samples are needed to detect small effects.

study-duration.name: study duration
study-duration.description: How long the study lasted. Longer studies can detect effects that take time to develop but are harder and more expensive to run.
study-duration.details: Duration matters for detecting adaptations. Strength gains appear within weeks, but muscle growth takes months to measure reliably. Long-term health outcomes require years of follow-up. Short studies may miss delayed effects or overestimate initial responses that plateau over time.

study-population.name: study population
study-population.description: Who was studied—their age, sex, training status, and health conditions. Results may not apply to people who differ from the study population.
study-population.details: Generalizability depends on how similar you are to study participants. Research on young trained men may not apply to older untrained women. Look for studies matching your demographics. Population characteristics include: sex, age group, training experience (untrained to elite), and health status (healthy or clinical conditions).

study-limitations.name: study limitations
study-limitations.description: Weaknesses or potential problems with a study that might affect how much you can trust its conclusions.
study-limitations.details: Common limitations include: small sample sizes, short duration, lack of control group, self-reported data, industry funding bias, non-representative populations, and high dropout rates. No study is perfect—what matters is whether limitations are serious enough to undermine the main conclusions.
